knowl.content:
Consider p(x) = {{polynomial_simplified}}. It will help you to know that
{{polynomial_simplified}} = {{polynomial}}.
Determine the end behavior of the graph.
Find the x-intercepts of the graph. Make sure you record their multiplicity.
Find the y-intercept of the graph.
Use the information from the previous three parts to sketch the graph of p. The y-intercept may be large, so feel free to have your y-axis be at a different scale than your x-axis.

item.p: As x \to -\infty, y \to {{left_end}}. As x \to \infty, y \to {{right_end}}.

The x-intercepts are {{x_ints}}. They have multiplicity {{mults}}, respectively. Remember, the graph passes through the x-axis when the multiplicity is odd and bounces off when the multiplicity is even.
